Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM - Sustainable Organic Synthesis Through Aerobic Carbon-Hydrogen Bond Functionalization Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Paul Floreancig of the University of Pittsburgh is developing environmentally benign approaches to oxidative bond forming reactions in organic synthesis. The advance is achieved through the use of inexpensive, non-toxic stoichiometric oxidants to regenerate quinones and through new transformations that significantly shorten the synthesis of biologically active molecules and their analogs. These efforts provide new routes to access complex structures through carbon-hydrogen bond functionalization in a manner that minimizes waste generation. Professor Floreancig is traveling to colleges and universities that have high populations of students from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the STEM fields to give seminars and to engage these students in discussions about scientific careers. In addition, Dr. Florencig will use the results of the research carried out under this award as the basis for lectures on green oxidation chemistry.

This project focuses on merging the exceptional capacity to access stabilized carbocations through carbon-hydrogen bond cleavage by the oxidant 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyano-1,4-benzoquinone (DDQ) with the environmental benefits of visible light-mediated photooxidation. DDQ is commonly used in stoichiometric quantities and generates significant quantities of reduction product waste. Visible light-mediated oxidations employ environmentally benign stoichiometric oxidants but do not show broad scope in oxidative cation formation. Using visible light-mediated oxidations to regenerate DDQ from the reduction product provides a path to retaining reactivity while reducing waste formation. Investigating several catalyst systems allow determination of the ideal catalyst structures for this new strategy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon–hydrogen bonds are in nearly all organic molecules. Converting these carbon–hydrogen bonds to carbon–carbon bonds provides a way to access complex structures that can have practical benefits, such as drugs, from simple, readily accessible structures. This efficient approach to molecular synthesis mitigates the environmental impact of the process by minimizing waste, but waste is not completely eliminated. The purposes of the studies that were supported by this grant were 1) to further minimize the waste that is created through the cleavage of carbon–hydrogen bonds by regenerating the agent that accomplishes this transformation, and 2) to show that carbon–hydrogen bond cleavage reactions allow for the synthesis of complex structures that have never been made and other structures that might be biologically relevant.

With respect to the first objective, we showed that we could regenerate an agent that cleaves carbon–hydrogen bonds called Bobbitt's salt with electricity through a process known as electrochemical oxidation. This allows us to use far less of the Bobbitt's salt in our reactions and, therefore, to generate far less waste. The improving efficiency of generating electricity assures that this will be a more environmentally friendly approach to this reaction. During this study we became interested in the structural features in molecules that allow for efficient reactions with a different carbon–hydrogen bond cleaving agent called DDQ. This led us to collaborate with a research group that studies chemical reactions computationally. This effort led us to devise a simple mathematical relationship that predicts the efficiency of reactions with DDQ. This will be important to future investigation that are based on the use of this common agent.

With respect to the second objective, we were able to use a carbon–hydrogen bond cleaving reaction in the synthesis of a naturally occuring antibiotic called divergolide E. This compound contains a subunit knowen as a bridged ketal. Prior approaches to the formation of bridged ketals require long synthetic sequences that generate substantial quantities of waste. Our carbon–hydrogen bond cleavage approach to this unit allowed us to bring in two complex subunits and connect them. This shortened the sequence of chemical transformations substantially and led us to prepare this molecule for the first time in a laboratory. We also used this fragment coupling approach to form analogs of a potential anti-cancer agent called bistramide A. Analog formation allows us to determine the essential molecular features for biological activity, but the effort can be very labor- and resourse-intensive. The carbon–hydrogen bond cleavage route allowed us to join in fragments to form products that could easily be converted to bistramide A analogs. These efforts led us to identify a compound that is nearly as effective as bistramide A at killing cancer cells but is far easier to prepare.

During the time in which we were conducting these studies we also became interested in oxidizing a class of molecules called alpha-boryl ethers. These compounds react with hydrogen peroxide and subsequently unravel to release a particular molecule. The molecule could be a drug or a dye that confirms that the reaction occured. We were able to show that we could release a dye inside of cells. This showed that we should be able to release drugs inside cells through a similar pathway. Numerous disease states are characterized by high concentrations of hydrogen peroxide, so we expect this strategy to be useful for releasing drugs solely at the site where they are needed. This will reduce drug doses and will minimize side effects.
